title: Simple Repetition
statementHtml:
Pasha loves prime numbers∗∗! Once again, in his attempts to find a new way to generate prime numbers, he became interested in an algorithm he found on the internet:

For example, for x=52x=52 and k=3k=3, we get y=525252y=525252, and for x=6x=6 and k=7k=7, we get y=6666666y=6666666.

Pasha really wants the resulting number yy to be prime, but he doesn't yet know how to check the primality of numbers generated by this algorithm. Help Pasha and tell him whether yy is prime!

∗∗An integer xx is considered prime if it has exactly 22 distinct divisors: 11 and xx. For example, 1313 is prime because it has only 22 divisors: 11 and 1313. Note that the number 11 is not prime, as it has only one divisor.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test consists of several sets of input data. The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100) — the number of sets of input data. The following lines describe the sets of input data.

The first and only line of each data set contains two integers: xx and kk (1≤x≤1091≤x≤109, 1≤k≤71≤k≤7).
outputSpecHtml:
For each set of input data, output «YES» (without quotes) if the resulting number yy will be prime, and «NO» otherwise.

You may output «Yes» and «No» in any case (for example, the strings «yES», «yes», and «Yes» will be recognized as positive answers).
tutorialHtml:
Let the number x have b digits in its decimal representation. What does it mean to write it k times? It can be shown that

y=x⋅100+x⋅10b+x⋅102b+⋯+x⋅10(k−1)b=x⋅(100+10b+102b+⋯+10(k−1)b)
It is clear that the second factor is greater than 1 when k>1. Thus, we can immediately note that when k>1 and x>1 simultaneously, the number y will never be prime, as it will have a divisor x, which is different from one and not equal to the number itself (since x=y100+10b+102b+⋯+10(k−1)b<y).

We are left to consider 2 cases:

  1. k=1, in this case the number x is written 1 time, that is, y=x. Thus, it is necessary to simply check the number x for primality, which can be done using a known algorithm in O(x−−√).
  2. x=1, in this case the number looks like: 11…11, that is, it is a number consisting of k ones. This number can be generated and checked for primality in O(10k−−−√)=O(10k/2). It is also possible to precompute prime numbers consisting only of ones and notice that for k≤7, the only prime number occurs when k=2, which is 11.
